item.title: List of reported UFO sightings
item.description:
List of Reported UFO Sightings ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia page serves as a dynamic list of notable reported sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), also referred to as Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena (UAP). It includes instances with claims of close encounters and alien abduction. The list acknowledges that most UFOs are eventually identified as known objects or phenomena, but a small percentage remain unexplained.

Antiquity ðŸ”—

This section details alleged UFO sightings from ancient times, drawing from historical texts and records.

  • c. 1450 BC: Tulli Papyrus: Describes an event during Thutmose III’s reign in Ancient Egypt, where a “star came down” and set fire to his adversaries. The account is based on the Tulli Papyrus.
  • 218 BC: Ships in the sky: A “phantom navy” was seen shining in the sky over Italia during the Roman Republic.
  • 76 BC: Spark from a falling star: A spark fell from a star in Asia (Roman province), grew to the size of the Moon, ascended, and transformed into a torch.
  • 73 BC: Flame-like wine-jars from the sky: During a battle between Lucullus and Mithridates VI of Pontus in Phrygia, a “huge, flame-like body” shaped like a wine-jar (pithos) fell between the two armies.
  • AD 65: Sky army: Flavius Josephus reported chariots “hurtling through the clouds” over Judaea before the First Jewishâ€“Roman War.
  • AD 196: Angel hair: Cassius Dio described a “fine rain resembling silver” descending from a clear sky upon the Forum of Augustus in Rome.

8th Century ðŸ”—

This section contains a single entry.

  • AD c. 740: Air ship of Clonmacnoise: “Ships with their crews were seen in the air” over Teltown and Clonmacnoise in Ireland.

16thâ€“17th Centuries ðŸ”—

This section details alleged UFO sightings from the 16th and 17th centuries.

  • 1561: Celestial phenomenon over Nuremberg: An aerial battle followed by the appearance of a black spear and hundreds of spheres and cylinders moving erratically over Nuremberg, Bavaria.
  • 1566: Celestial phenomenon over Basel: A broadsheet depicted numerous spherical objects appearing out of the sun over Basel, Switzerland.
  • 1609: Gwanghaegun period UFO Turmoil: Multiple witnesses in Joseon (Korea) described a Halo or washbowl that was divided in two in the sky.

19th Century ðŸ”—

This section details alleged UFO sightings from the 19th century.

  • 1883: Bonilla observation: Astronomer JosÃ© Bonilla photographed hundreds of dark objects crossing the sun at Zacatecas Observatory in Mexico.
  • 1896-1897: Mystery airships: Reports of strange airships and lights appeared in newspapers across California and other states. Descriptions included bright lights, cigar-shaped bodies, movable wings, and metallic hulls.
  • 1897: Aurora, Texas, UFO incident: Local correspondent S.E. Hayden reported the crash of an airship piloted by an alien in Aurora, Texas. The pilot was allegedly buried in the local cemetery.

20th Century ðŸ”—

This section details alleged UFO sightings from the 20th century, split into two subsections.

1900â€“1949 ðŸ”—

  • 1904: USS Supply: Three “bright red” objects in geometrical formation flight pattern were observed by three crew members about 300 miles from California.
  • 1907: Mihal Grameno UFO: Albanian fighters stationed on a mountain top witnessed a shiny object suspended in the air.
  • 1909: New Zealand airship sightings: Moving and whirring lights were reported in the sky around Otago, New Zealand.
  • 1917: Miracle of the Sun: Thousands of people in FÃ¡tima, Portugal, claimed to see bizarre solar activity, later interpreted as a mass UFO sighting by some.
  • 1926: Nicholas Roerich UFO sighting: Nicholas Roerich reported an oval in the sky above his caravan in Tibet, later interpreted as a “flying saucer.”
  • 1933: Frank Smythe UFO sighting: Frank Smythe witnessed two spots hovering and pulsating in the sky during the 1933 Mount Everest expedition.
  • 1940s: Foo fighters: Allied fighter pilots reported colorful balls of light following their aircraft at high speeds over Europe during World War II.
  • 1941: Cape Girardeau UFO legend: A local legend tells of a crashed flying saucer near Cape Girardeau, Missouri, where a reverend administered last rites to the dying crew.
  • 1942: Battle of Los Angeles: U.S. radar stations picked up an unidentified aerial object, leading to anti-aircraft artillery firing thousands of rounds over Los Angeles.
  • 1942: Army Air Corps Flying School: Control tower operator observes two reddish colored round objects descend-hover-accelerate away near Columbus, Missouri.
  • 1944: 468th Bomb Group: An object of “intense red or orange” color followed a bomber for about 8 minutes near Palembang, Sumatra.
  • 1945: Trinity UFO Case: Conflicting accounts emerged of an avocado-shaped craft piloted by insectoid aliens crashing at the site of the first atomic bomb detonation.
  • 1946: The Ghost Rockets: Thousands of UFO sightings were reported over Europe, leading to investigations by the Swedish and Greek governments.
  • 1946: Ã„ngelholm UFO memorial: Swedish entrepreneur GÃ¶sta Carlsson attributed his success to a 1946 UFO encounter, commemorated with a monument in Ã„ngelholm, Sweden.
  • 1947: Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting: Private pilot Kenneth Arnold reported seeing a group of reflective craft moving at high speeds near Mount Rainier, Washington, coining the term “flying saucers.”
  • 1947: 1947 flying disc craze: Over 800 similar sightings were reported after the Kenneth Arnold sighting.
  • 1947: Flight 105 UFO sighting: A United Airlines crew witnessed nine unidentified objects en route from Boise, Idaho, to Pendleton, Oregon.
  • 1947: Rhodes UFO photographs: William Albert Rhodes took photographs of a silent grey object in Phoenix, Arizona.
  • 1947: The Roswell Incident: A press release announced the “capture” of a “flying saucer” near Roswell, New Mexico, later explained as a crashed weather balloon.
  • 1947: Maury Island hoax: Fred Crisman mailed an account of a UFO encounter to Raymond A. Palmer, claiming his dog was killed and his son injured by debris.
  • 1948: The Green Fireballs: Reports of green flares streaking across the sky were investigated by the US Air Force.
  • 1948: Mantell UFO incident: Captain Thomas F. Mantell died in the crash of his P-51 Mustang fighter plane near Franklin, Kentucky, after being sent in pursuit of an unidentified flying object.
  • 1948: Aztec, New Mexico UFO hoax: Conmen Silas Newton and Leo Gebauer sold “magnetic oil-detecting machines” based on a story about replicated technology from a crashed spaceship.
  • 1948: Chiles-Whitted UFO encounter: Clarence Chiles and John Whitted, commercial pilots, reported that their airplane had nearly collided with a UFO near Montgomery, Alabama.
  • 1948: Gorman dogfight: A US Air Force pilot sighted and pursued a UFO for 27 minutes over Fargo, North Dakota.

1950â€“1974 ðŸ”—

  • 1950: McMinnville UFO photographs: A farmer took pictures of a purported “flying saucer” near McMinnville, Oregon.
  • 1950: Mariana UFO incident: The manager of Great Falls’ pro baseball team took color film of two UFOs flying over Great Falls, Montana.
  • 1951: Sioux City mystery plane incident: Two pilots and a military officer passenger aboard a commercial DC-3 reported being buzzed by an unidentified straight-winged plane over Sioux City, Iowa.
  • 1951: Lubbock Lights: Several lights in V-shaped formations were repeatedly spotted flying over Lubbock, Texas.
  • 1952: Wonsan-Sunchon UFO incident: Four American military personnel aboard two different B-29 bombers reported seeing an orange globe-shaped light over two different cities in northern Korea.
  • 1952: Washington, D.C. UFO incident: A series of sightings accompanied radar contacts in the Washington, D.C. area.
  • 1952: Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting: William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, pilots of a DC-4 airliner

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_reported_UFO_sightings

item.title: UFO sightings in Africa
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in Africa ðŸ”—

This is a compilation of reported Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) sightings across various countries in Africa.

Algeria ðŸ”—

This section details alleged UFO sightings during the Algerian War (1954â€“1962) around conflict zones. A specific incident from March 1958 is highlighted, where a soldier reported witnessing a large, elliptical craft with green lights and a beam of light. In March 1975, multiple UFOs were reportedly observed by several people across the country.

Benin ðŸ”—

This section simply states that reports were received from Benin, but does not provide any specific details.

Botswana ðŸ”—

This section lists two specific UFO sightings in Botswana: one in the Okavango Delta on June 25, 2016, and another in Gaberone on May 14, 2008.

Morocco ðŸ”—

This section describes three UFO sightings in July 1952. The first involved two elongated flying saucers spotted by policemen above Had Kourt. The second involved inhabitants of Fedala spotting a blue-green, ball-shaped object. The third involved a couple observing another flying saucer.

Senegal ðŸ”—

This section details a UFO sighting above Dakar on July 3, 1952. The object was described as a flat, tapered saucer surrounded by flames, moving at high speed.

South Africa ðŸ”—

This section refers to a main article dedicated to UFO sightings in South Africa.

Sudan ðŸ”—

This section describes a UFO sighting in January 2018 over Khartoum. The Sudanese military identified it as a potential satellite, possibly the failed US satellite Zuma, but admitted they could not clearly identify the object.

Tunisia ðŸ”—

This section recounts a UFO sighting in July 1969, where many observers, including US embassy officials, reported a large, two-part green-blue object in the sky of Tunis. The object reportedly exploded, forming a greenish circular cloud.

Zimbabwe ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the Ruwa UFO incident on September 14, 1994, where 62 children from a school in Ruwa witnessed the landing of a large spaceship and smaller ones. The children described the aliens as having large heads, slits for mouths, and dark suits. American psychiatrist John E. Mack interviewed the children and concluded that the incident was likely not mass hysteria, as the children gave consistent accounts.

Bibliography ðŸ”—

This section lists two books related to UFOs in Africa:

  • UFOs Over Africa by Cynthia Hind
  • The ufo issue in Central Africa (Gabon, Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo) by Jann Halexander

References ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of citations used as sources for the information presented in the article.

External links ðŸ”—

This section contains a link to a YouTube video titled “UFO Sightings in Algeria 22/01/2008” showing a UFO sighting in Taguercift village, Algeria.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Africa

item.title: UFO sightings in Australia
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings in the nation of Australia ðŸ”—

This article lists alleged UFO sightings in Australia, spanning from the pre-1900s to recent times.

Pre 1900 ðŸ”—

This section details an 1868 sighting in Parramatta, New South Wales, where Alderman Frederick Birmingham reported seeing an ark-like object floating in the sky before landing in Parramatta Park.

1950s ðŸ”—

This section mentions a 1954 sighting in Gawler, South Australia, where three people observed a white UFO flying overhead, followed by an RAAF jet.

1960s ðŸ”—

This section includes two notable events:

  • A 1966 incident in Tully, Queensland, where a farmer reported a large saucer-shaped object and a “nest” of reeds in a swamp.
  • The 1966 Westall High School UFO incident in Clayton South, Victoria, where many students and staff claimed to have witnessed a UFO flying over the school and descending into a paddock.

1970s ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the Valentich Disappearance in 1978. Frederick Valentich, a pilot, disappeared while flying a Cessna 182 over Bass Strait to King Island (Tasmania). He reported to Melbourne air traffic control that he was being accompanied by an unknown aircraft.

1980s ðŸ”—

This section describes a 1988 sighting in South Australia’s Nullarbor Plain. A family reported seeing a “big glowing ball” that resembled “an egg in an egg cup.”

1990s ðŸ”—

This section details two incidents:

  • In 1993, Eric Thomason photographed a craft hovering around Maslin Beach.
  • Also in 1993, Kelly Cahill from Melbourne claimed to have seen a large craft over the road in the Dandenong Ranges near Belgrave, Victoria, and further claimed to have been abducted by aliens.

2012 ðŸ”—

This section describes an alleged encounter in Frankston South, Victoria. A resident, K.T., reported being hit by a blinding light and later encountering a tall, white humanoid being identifying as a “Paladeian” from the “Star Cluster Pladieas.” K.T. claimed to have communicated telepathically with the being, experiencing paralysis and lost time during the encounter.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related topics, including the Bass Strait Triangle and a general list of reported UFO sightings.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including news articles and websites.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Australia

item.title: UFO sightings in Albania
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings in Albania ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Albania, spanning from 1907 to 2010.

1907 ðŸ”—

This section details the earliest documented UFO encounter in Albania, recorded in the diary of Mihal Grameno, a journalist, writer, and activist. He recounts an incident during the years 1907â€“1908 while fighting alongside Ã‡erÃ§iz Topulli’s guerrilla group. Grameno describes a shiny object that hovered in the air before disappearing.

8 July 1933 ðŸ”—

This section mentions a report addressed to the Prefecture of Milan regarding an unusual incident in VlorÃ«. It states that two airplanes changed direction in a way that was considered abnormal for the technology of the time.

18 July 1947 ðŸ”—

This section references an FBI report that mentions UFOs, also referred to as “saucers,” being observed in various locations worldwide, including Albania.

January 1963 ðŸ”—

This section describes an incident in the village of KallamishtÃ«z in the Kurvelesh area, where residents reported seeing a bright object in the sky. The Albanian authorities attempted to explain the sighting as a new jet plane model used by the Albanian Air Force.

1969 ðŸ”—

This section recounts an experience of Ilir Malindi, a lawyer, in the Pirogoshi Canyon above Ã‡orovodÃ«. Malindi and others witnessed two luminous, circular objects that illuminated the canyon before rapidly disappearing into the sky.

1 August 1990 ðŸ”—

This section details an event experienced by GÃ«zim Dapi, an environmental engineer, while serving in the military in ShkodÃ«r. Dapi describes seeing a series of lights arranged in a diamond pattern moving at high speed with minimal noise. Other soldiers from different anti-aircraft units reported the same sighting.

12 July 1993 ðŸ”—

This section describes a sighting in CÃ«rrik, Elbasan, where a glowing flying object appeared in the sky. Eyewitnesses reported sudden and quick movements of the object, which disappeared after approximately two hours.

4 May 2006 ðŸ”—

This section recounts the most famous case of UFO encounters in Albania, which occurred in the village of Roskovec. Residents, including an adult woman and two children, reported an unidentified object landing in their town. Evidence included three double-banded black circles in the asphalt. Witnesses described a sudden darkness, strong wind, and the object’s appearance as an oval disc with a gray color and a thin blue line.

6 March 2007 ðŸ”—

This section details a sighting reported by Coast Guard officer Admir Jemishaj and his commander in Seman, Fier. They observed an unmoving object in space that had a dazzling shine, changed colors, and had a disc-like shape.

24 December 2008 ðŸ”—

This section describes an encounter reported by four hunters from Elbasan. They claimed to have seen a flying disk in a village near Peqin. The hunters reported being blinded by a bright blue light and a vertical red light, which caused their vehicle’s engine to die.

21 July 2009 ðŸ”—

This section recounts a sighting in VlorÃ«, where fishermen reported seeing an unidentified flying object shaped like a satellite in the area behind Karaburun. The object emitted a trail of smoke and was gray to white.

7 August 2010 ðŸ”—

This section details a sighting in Tirana, where a woman, Rezmie Lulo, and her family witnessed three strange, orange, spherical objects shining in the sky. The objects moved at immense speed, and the Albanian Army and Civil Aviation Authority did not provide official information about the objects.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related articles, including “UFO sightings in Kosovo” and “List of reported UFO sightings.”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including news articles, books, and YouTube videos.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Albania

item.title: Mutual UFO Network
item.description:
Mutual UFO Network ðŸ”—

The Mutual UFO Network (MUFON) is a US-based non-profit organization dedicated to the scientific study of UFOs. Founded in 1969, it has grown to include over 4,000 members worldwide, with chapters in over 43 countries and all 50 US states. MUFON aims to investigate UFO sightings and provide information to the public.

History ðŸ”—

MUFON was originally established as the Midwest UFO Network on May 31, 1969, in Quincy, Illinois, by Allen R. Utke, Walter H. Andrus, Jr., John F. Schuessler, and others. It was renamed the Mutual UFO Network in 1973 due to its expansion. In July 2020, Executive Director Jan Harzan was arrested on charges of soliciting sex from a minor and was subsequently removed from his position.

Operation ðŸ”—

Headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, MUFON has chapters throughout the U.S. and internationally. It hosts an annual international symposium and publishes the monthly MUFON UFO Journal. In 2015, MUFON founded Mutual UFO Network University, an unaccredited online institution for training UFO investigators. The organization has over 500 field investigators who investigate potential physical evidence of extraterrestrial craft.

Criticism ðŸ”—

Pseudoscience ðŸ”—

MUFON has faced criticism for its focus on pseudoscience, including topics like alien abduction, conspiracy theories, and human-ET hybrids. Critics argue that MUFON’s investigations lack scientific rigor and that its researchers are often not scientists.

Officers and donors with far-right viewpoints ðŸ”—

In 2018, Newsweek reported on anti-immigrant, anti-trans, and anti-Muslim sentiments among MUFON officials and donors, including J. Z. Knight and John Ventre. This led to resignations from members like Chris Cogswell and James Clarkson. In 2020, Vice reported that Ken Pfeifer, head of MUFON’s Rhode Island chapter, posted racist content on Facebook.

Popular culture ðŸ”—

MUFON has been mentioned in various television shows and news articles, including:

Television ðŸ”—

  • UFOs Over Earth (2008)
  • UFO Hunters (2008)
  • The X-Files
  • Ancient Aliens
  • Hangar 1: The UFO Files
  • 9-1-1: Lone Star (Season 3, Episode 6 “The ATX-Files”)

News ðŸ”—

  • The New York Times article “People Are Seeing U.F.O.s Everywhere, and This Book Proves It”
  • Forbes article “MUFON, America’s UFO Experts, Discuss Roswell And Possible Cover-Ups”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MUFON

item.title: Mutual UFO Network
item.description:
Mutual UFO Network ðŸ”—

The Mutual UFO Network (MUFON) is a US-based non-profit organization dedicated to the scientific study of UFOs. Founded in 1969, it has grown to include over 4,000 members worldwide, with chapters and representatives in numerous countries and all 50 US states.

History ðŸ”—

Originally established as the Midwest UFO Network in Quincy, Illinois, on May 31, 1969, by Allen R. Utke, Walter H. Andrus, Jr., and John F. Schuessler, among others. Many early members were associated with the SKYLOOK newsletter and the Aerial Phenomena Research Organization (APRO). The organization expanded and was renamed the Mutual UFO Network in 1973. In July 2020, Executive Director Jan Harzan was arrested on charges of soliciting sex from a minor and was subsequently removed from his position.

Operation ðŸ”—

MUFON is headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, and has chapters in every U.S. state. It holds an annual international symposium and publishes the monthly MUFON UFO Journal. In 2015, MUFON founded Mutual UFO Network University, an unaccredited online institution that trains members to investigate UFO sightings. The network claims over 500 field investigators and specialized teams to investigate potential physical evidence of extraterrestrial craft. Volunteers are trained to interview witnesses, conduct research, and analyze evidence, requiring them to pass an exam and a background check. MUFON’s website features a newsroom and case management system.

Criticism ðŸ”—

Pseudoscience ðŸ”—

MUFON has faced criticism for its focus on pseudoscience. Critics argue that the organization’s conferences and publications delve into topics like alien abduction, conspiracy theories, human-ET hybrids, hypnotic regression, and repressed memories, which are considered unscientific. The qualifications of the amateur volunteers who examine UFO reports have also been questioned.

Officers and donors with far-right viewpoints ðŸ”—

In April 2018, Newsweek reported evidence of anti-immigrant, anti-trans, and anti-Muslim sentiments among MUFON officials and donors, including J. Z. Knight and former MUFON State Director for Pennsylvania John Ventre. These individuals have publicly expressed racist and/or anti-Semitic views. This led to resignations from MUFON, including former Director of Research Chris Cogswell and former board member and Washington State Director James Clarkson. Erica Lukes, former MUFON State Director for Utah, described MUFON as unwilling to adequately address sexual harassment. In 2020, Vice magazine reported that Ken Pfeifer, head of MUFON’s Rhode Island chapter, posted racist memes and comments on Facebook.

Popular culture ðŸ”—

MUFON has been mentioned in various television shows, including:

  • UFOs Over Earth (Discovery Channel)
  • UFO Hunters (History Channel)
  • The X-Files
  • Ancient Aliens (History Channel)
  • Hangar 1: The UFO Files
  • 9-1-1: Lone Star

It has also been mentioned in news articles in The New York Times and Forbes.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_UFO_Network

item.title: Black triangle (UFO)
item.description:
Black Triangles ðŸ”—

Black triangles are a type of unidentified flying object (UFO) characterized by their triangular shape and dark color. These objects are typically observed at night and are often described as large, silent, hovering, moving slowly, and displaying pulsating, colored lights that can be turned off.

British Sightings and UK Ministry of Defence Report ðŸ”—

This section discusses the analysis of black triangle sightings by the UK Ministry of Defence in a declassified report called Project Condign. The report suggests that many unexplained UAP reports could be attributed to atmospheric gaseous electrically charged buoyant plasmas. It also mentions that some observations might be due to meteor entry into the atmosphere. The report proposes that a field with undetermined characteristics can exist between charged buoyant objects in loose formation, creating a triangular shape where light reflection doesn’t occur. A recommendation from the report advises aircraft to avoid intercepting these objects and instead position them astern to reduce collision risks. The report also speculates that plasma formations could induce vivid but incorrect perceptions in observers. Mark Stenhoff and Adrian James are mentioned as authors who doubt the scientific veracity of the Project Condign report.

Other Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details various black triangle UFO sightings reported across different locations and time periods.

1980s Hudson Valley Sightings ðŸ”—

During the early 1980s, hundreds of people reported seeing UFOs over or near the Hudson River in New York state. These objects were described as hovering or slowly flying V-shaped objects with colorful lights. Some pilots claimed responsibility for these sightings, stating that the objects were ultralight aircraft flown in formation.

1989â€“1992 Belgian Wave ðŸ”—

The Belgian UFO wave began in November 1989. On November 29, over thirty groups of witnesses and three police groups documented a large, flat, triangular object with lights underneath flying at low altitude without making any sound. A report titled The Belgian UFO Wave of 1989â€“1992 â€“ A Neglected Hypothesis suggests that some sightings could be explained by helicopters, with the lack of noise attributed to engine noise in witnesses’ automobiles or strong winds. The Belgian Air Force attempted to intercept an object detected by radar during this wave, but the pilots did not visually confirm the object. Brian Dunning is mentioned as a skeptic who disputes the entire Belgian UFO wave.

1997 Phoenix Lights Incident ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the widely reported “Phoenix Lights” events, where multiple unidentified objects were observed near Phoenix, Arizona, beginning on March 13, 1997. Some objects appeared in a large “V” formation and lingered for several minutes. Residents reported that one of the black triangles was over a mile wide and drifted slowly over their houses. The US Air Force concluded that the military had been testing aircraft-launched flares during that period.

2000 Southern Illinois Incident ðŸ”—

The “St. Clair Triangle” sighting occurred on January 5, 2000, over several towns in Southern Illinois. The incident was featured in television shows, and Sufjan Stevens included it in his song “Concerning the UFO Sighting Near Highland, Illinois.” The FAA suggested that the sightings might have been due to an advertising blimp operated by the American Blimp Company. William Stage is mentioned as a source, and Eric Mack is cited for debunking his own UFO sighting.

2004â€“2006 Tinley Park Lights ðŸ”—

Multiple witnesses in Tinley Park and Oak Forest, Illinois, reported seeing three red lights hovering in a triangular formation on several occasions between 2004 and 2006. Some witnesses captured the lights in photographs and videos. The incident was examined in a Dateline NBC episode and in an episode of the television series UFO Hunters. Julie Dekker is mentioned in connection with remembering the “Tinley Park lights.”

2008 Stephenville, Texas ðŸ”—

A mass sighting occurred in Stephenville, Texas, around January 8, 2008. The Netflix documentary series Encounters claims that the black triangles seen had what looked like insects or a praying mantis inside. Angelia Joiner is mentioned as reporting on the possible UFO sighting in the Stephenville Empire-Tribune.

Military Aircraft ðŸ”—

This section explores the possibility that classified military aircraft could be responsible for many black triangle UFO reports. Sightings have been reported over Antelope Valley in southern California, near military research and testing areas like Edwards Air Force Base and United States Air Force Plant 42. The National Institute for Discovery Science suggested that black triangles might be U.S. Air Force craft. The Northrop TR-3A Black Manta, a speculative surveillance aircraft, is mentioned, but its existence is not confirmed. Gregory T. Pope is cited regarding America’s new secret aircraft, and Global Security is referenced for information on the TR-3A. Geoscientist Ben McGee is identified as suggesting that border patrol drones with infrared lights could explain some black triangles. Natalie Wolchover is cited in relation to McGee’s explanation.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_triangle_(UFO)

item.title: 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident
item.description:
Washington, D.C. UFO Incident (1952) ðŸ”—

This article details a series of unidentified flying object (UFO) sightings that occurred in Washington, D.C., during July 1952. These sightings, known as the “Washington flap,” the “Washington National Airport Sightings,” or the “Invasion of Washington,” garnered significant media attention and became one of the most well-known UFO incidents.

1952 UFO flap ðŸ”—

This section describes the broader context of the 1952 UFO flap, a period of heightened media and public interest in UFO sightings. It notes the surge in reported sightings during the summer of 1952, with the US Air Force receiving over 717 new reports, compared to 615 in the previous four years. It mentions the role of media coverage, including a Life magazine article titled “Have We Visitors From Space?” which is believed to have contributed to the increased sightings. The section also highlights other notable sightings and reports leading up to the Washington D.C. events, including a UFO report filed by Hughes Aircraft Company in Los Angeles and an interception of a UFO over Boston by F-94s. The Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting over Chesapeake Bay is also mentioned. Edward J. Ruppelt, the director of Project Blue Book, is a key figure mentioned in this section.

Sightings over Washington, D.C. ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the specific UFO sightings that occurred over Washington, D.C., on two consecutive Saturday nights in July 1952.

Night of July 19 ðŸ”—

This subsection details the events of the first night of sightings, beginning with air traffic controller Edward Nugent spotting seven objects on radar at Washington National Airport. Senior air-traffic controller Harry Barnes also witnessed the objects and noted their unusual movements. Controllers at the airport’s control tower, Howard Cocklin and Joe Zacko, also reported seeing unidentified blips on radar and a “bright light” in the sky. Airman William Brady at Andrews Air Force Base reported seeing an “orange ball of fire.” S.C. Pierman, a Capital Airlines pilot, observed six “white, tailless, fast-moving lights” near his plane. Staff Sgt. Charles Davenport at Andrews Air Force Base observed an orange-red light exhibiting unusual movements. Two F-94 Starfire jet fighters were dispatched from New Castle Air Force Base in Delaware, but the objects vanished from radar upon their arrival, only to reappear after the jets left.

Publicity and Air Force reaction ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the widespread media coverage of the July 19-20 sightings, which made front-page headlines across the nation. It mentions the involvement of USAF Captain Edward J. Ruppelt, the supervisor of Project Blue Book, who was in Washington at the time but faced difficulties in investigating the sightings. The section also notes that an Air Force radar specialist, Captain Roy James, suggested that unusual weather conditions could have caused the radar targets.

Night of July 26 ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the events of the second night of sightings, beginning with a pilot and stewardess on a National Airlines flight reporting lights above their plane. Radar centers at National Airport and Andrews AFB tracked more unknown objects. USAF master sergeant Charles E. Cummings visually observed the objects at Andrews. Albert M. Chop, the press spokesman for Project Blue Book, arrived at National Airport. Two F-94 Starfire jet fighters from New Castle Air Force Base were scrambled. Captain John McHugo, the flight leader, saw nothing, but his wingman, Lieutenant William Patterson, saw four white “glows” and chased them. USAF Major Dewey Fournet, Project Blue Book’s liaison at the Pentagon, and Lt. John Holcomb, a United States Navy radar specialist, arrived at the radar center at National Airport. Civilian aircraft also reported glowing objects that corresponded to radar blips.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This section briefly mentions a report from West Palm Beach scoutmaster Sonny DesVergers, who claimed to have been burned by a flying disc on August 19.

Air Force explanation ðŸ”—

This section details the Air Force’s official explanation for the sightings. Major Generals John Samford, USAF Director of Intelligence, and Roger M. Ramey, USAF Director of Operations, held a press conference at the Pentagon on July 29, 1952. Samford stated that the visual sightings could be explained as misidentified aerial phenomena, such as stars or meteors, and the unknown radar targets could be attributed to temperature inversion. The crew of a B-25 bomber and Air Force Captain Harold May are mentioned as witnesses who supported the Air Force’s explanation. The CAA’s Technical Development and Evaluation Center also conducted an analysis that supported the temperature inversion theory. Donald Menzel and Philip Klass are mentioned as prominent UFO skeptics who also supported the temperature inversion/mirage hypothesis.

Criticisms ðŸ”—

This subsection presents criticisms of the Air Force’s explanation. Edward J. Ruppelt, in his book, noted that radar and control tower personnel, as well as some Air Force officers, disagreed with the Air Force’s explanation. Michael Wertheimer, a researcher for the Condon Report, stated that radar witnesses still disputed the Air Force explanation in 1966. Former radar controller Howard Cocklin maintained his belief that he saw an object over Washington National Airport.

White House concern and CIA interest ðŸ”—

This section discusses the concern that the sightings caused within the White House and the CIA. President Harry Truman requested an explanation of the sightings and radar returns. CIA historian Gerald Haines noted that the Truman administration was alarmed by the sightings. The CIA formed a special study group to review the situation and recommended continued monitoring of the problem. This concern led to the creation of the Robertson Panel in January 1953.

The Robertson Panel ðŸ”—

This section describes the creation and findings of the Robertson Panel, formed in January 1953 due to the high number of UFO reports. The panel, chaired by physicist Howard P. Robertson, consisted of prominent scientists who examined UFO cases collected by Project Blue Book. The panel dismissed most cases as not representing anything unusual or threatening and recommended that the Air Force and Project Blue Book focus on debunking UFO reports.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section notes the appearances of the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident in popular culture, specifically in the History Channel television series Project Blue Book and the Netflix series Top Secret UFO Projects Declassified.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the notes and sources used in the article.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external resources related to the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident, including articles from the CIA, Fold3, Saturday Night Uforia, and Ghosts of DC.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1952_UFO_flap

item.title: 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident
item.description:
1952 Washington, D.C., UFO Incident ðŸ”—

This article details a series of unidentified flying object (UFO) sightings that occurred in Washington, D.C., during July 1952. These sightings, known as the “Washington flap,” “Washington National Airport Sightings,” or the “Invasion of Washington,” garnered significant media attention and became one of the most well-known UFO incidents.

1952 UFO Flap ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the Washington D.C. sightings by describing the broader wave of UFO reports that occurred during the summer of 1952. It notes the surge in media coverage and the increased number of UFO reports received by the US Air Force. Key figures mentioned include Edward J. Ruppelt, the director of Project Blue Book, and Donald Howard Menzel, an astrophysicist who proposed that the sightings were optical mirages. The section also references a Life magazine article that explored the possibility of extraterrestrial spaceships, which is believed to have contributed to the increased sightings. The Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting over Chesapeake Bay is also mentioned.

Sightings over Washington, D.C. ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the specific UFO sightings that occurred over Washington, D.C., on two consecutive Saturday nights in July 1952.

Night of July 19 ðŸ”—

This subsection details the events of the first night of sightings, beginning with air traffic controller Edward Nugent spotting seven objects on radar at Washington National Airport. Senior air-traffic controller Harry Barnes and controllers at the airport’s control tower, Howard Cocklin and Joe Zacko, also witnessed the objects. Airman William Brady at Andrews Air Force Base reported seeing an orange ball of fire. S.C. Pierman, a Capital Airlines pilot, observed six white lights. Radar centers at National Airport and Andrews Air Force Base tracked an object hovering over a radio beacon. Two Air Force F-94 Starfire jets were dispatched from New Castle Air Force Base in Delaware, but the objects vanished before their arrival.

Publicity and Air Force reaction ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the media frenzy that followed the July 19-20 sightings. It mentions that USAF Captain Edward J. Ruppelt, supervisor of Project Blue Book, was in Washington at the time and frustrated by his inability to investigate the sightings properly.

Night of July 26 ðŸ”—

This subsection recounts the events of the second night of sightings. A pilot and stewardess on a National Airlines flight observed lights above their plane. Radar centers at National Airport and Andrews AFB tracked more unknown objects. USAF master sergeant Charles E. Cummings visually observed the objects at Andrews. Albert M. Chop, the press spokesman for Project Blue Book, arrived at National Airport. Two U.S. Air Force F-94 Starfire jets from New Castle Air Force Base in Delaware were dispatched. Captain John McHugo, the flight leader, saw nothing, but his wingman, Lieutenant William Patterson, saw four white “glows” and chased them. USAF Major Dewey Fournet and Lt. John Holcomb, a United States Navy radar specialist, arrived at the radar center at National Airport. Civilian aircraft also reported glowing objects.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This section briefly mentions a report from West Palm Beach scoutmaster Sonny DesVergers, who claimed to have been burned by a flying disc in August 1952.

Air Force Explanation ðŸ”—

This section details the official Air Force explanation for the Washington D.C. UFO incidents. Major Generals John Samford and Roger M. Ramey held a press conference at the Pentagon on July 29, 1952, where they attributed the visual sightings to misidentified aerial phenomena like stars or meteors, and the radar targets to temperature inversions. The crew of a B-25 bomber and Air Force Captain Harold May provided accounts supporting the Air Force’s explanation. The CAA’s Technical Development and Evaluation Center also concluded that temperature inversions were present during the sightings. Donald Menzel and Philip Klass are mentioned as prominent UFO skeptics who supported the temperature inversion/mirage hypothesis.

Criticisms ðŸ”—

This subsection presents criticisms of the Air Force’s explanation. Edward J. Ruppelt, radar and control tower personnel, and some Air Force officers disagreed with the official explanation. Michael Wertheimer, a researcher for the Condon Report, stated that radar witnesses still disputed the Air Force explanation. Former radar controller Howard Cocklin maintained that he saw an object on radar and out the window.

White House Concern and CIA Interest ðŸ”—

This section describes the concern that the sightings caused within the White House and the CIA. President Harry Truman requested an explanation of the sightings. CIA historian Gerald Haines notes Truman’s alarm and the CIA’s subsequent formation of a special study group. Edward Tauss reported for the group that most UFO sightings could be easily explained, but recommended continued monitoring. This concern led to the creation of the Robertson Panel in January 1953.

The Robertson Panel ðŸ”—

This section details the creation and findings of the Robertson Panel, formed in January 1953 due to the high number of UFO reports. The panel, chaired by physicist Howard P. Robertson, consisted of prominent scientists who examined UFO cases collected by Project Blue Book. The panel dismissed most cases as not threatening national security and recommended that the Air Force focus on debunking UFO reports.

In Popular Culture ðŸ”—

This section notes the appearances of the 1952 Washington D.C. UFO incident in popular media, specifically in the History Channel television series Project Blue Book and the Netflix series Top Secret UFO Projects Declassified.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1952_Washington,_D.C.,_UFO_incident

item.title: 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident
item.description:
Washington, D.C. UFO Incident ðŸ”—

This article details the series of unidentified flying object (UFO) sightings that occurred in Washington, D.C., during July 1952. These sightings, known as the “Washington flap,” “Washington National Airport Sightings,” or the “Invasion of Washington,” garnered significant media attention and became one of the most well-known UFO incidents.

1952 UFO flap ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the Washington D.C. sightings by describing the broader wave of UFO reports that occurred in the summer of 1952. It highlights the unprecedented media attention and the large number of UFO reports received by the US Air Force. Key figures mentioned include Edward J. Ruppelt, the director of Project Blue Book, who noted the extensive media coverage. The section also mentions events leading up to the Washington sightings, such as an explosion in Seattle, an Associated Press report on the Air Force’s interest in UFOs, and articles in Life and Look magazines discussing the phenomenon.

Sightings over Washington, D.C. ðŸ”—

This section details the specific UFO sightings that occurred over Washington, D.C., on two consecutive Saturday nights in July 1952.

Night of July 19 ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the initial sightings on July 19, 1952. Edward Nugent, an air traffic controller at Washington National Airport, first spotted seven objects on radar. Harry Barnes, a senior air-traffic controller, confirmed the unusual movements of the objects. Controllers at the airport’s control tower, Howard Cocklin and Joe Zacko, also observed the radar blips and a “bright light” in the sky. Airman William Brady at Andrews Air Force Base reported seeing an “orange ball of fire.” S.C. Pierman, a Capital Airlines pilot, observed six “white, tailless, fast-moving lights.” The section also mentions radar tracking of an object hovering over a radio beacon. The arrival of two Air Force F-94 Starfire jets from New Castle Air Force Base temporarily dispersed the objects.

Publicity and Air Force reaction ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the widespread media coverage of the July 19-20 sightings. It mentions that USAF Captain Edward J. Ruppelt, supervisor of Project Blue Book, was in Washington at the time but faced difficulties in investigating the sightings. The section also notes that an Air Force radar specialist, Captain Roy James, suggested that unusual weather conditions could have caused the radar targets.

Night of July 26 ðŸ”—

This subsection details the events of July 26, 1952. A pilot and stewardess on a National Airlines flight reported seeing lights above their plane. Radar centers at National Airport and Andrews AFB tracked more unknown objects. USAF master sergeant Charles E. Cummings visually observed the objects at Andrews. Albert M. Chop, the press spokesman for Project Blue Book, arrived at National Airport. Two F-94 Starfire jets were scrambled, with Lieutenant William Patterson reporting seeing four white “glows.” Major Dewey Fournet, Project Blue Book’s liaison at the Pentagon, and Lt. John Holcomb, a United States Navy radar specialist, arrived at National Airport. Civilian aircraft also reported glowing objects.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This section briefly mentions a report from August 19, where West Palm Beach scoutmaster Sonny DesVergers claimed to have been burned by a flying disc.

Air Force explanation ðŸ”—

This section describes the Air Force’s official explanation for the sightings. Major Generals John Samford and Roger M. Ramey held a press conference at the Pentagon on July 29, 1952, stating that the visual sightings could be explained as misidentified aerial phenomena and the radar targets by temperature inversion. The crew of a B-25 bomber and Air Force Captain Harold May provided accounts supporting the Air Force’s explanation. The CAA’s Technical Development and Evaluation Center also concluded that a temperature inversion was present during the sightings. Donald Menzel and Philip Klass are mentioned as prominent UFO skeptics who supported the temperature inversion/mirage hypothesis.

Criticisms ðŸ”—

This subsection presents criticisms of the Air Force’s explanation. Edward J. Ruppelt, radar and control tower personnel, and some Air Force officers disagreed with the official explanation. Michael Wertheimer, a researcher for the Condon Report, stated that radar witnesses still disputed the Air Force explanation. Former radar controller Howard Cocklin maintained that he saw an object on the radar screen and out the window.

White House concern and CIA interest ðŸ”—

This section discusses the concern of President Harry Truman and the CIA regarding the UFO sightings. Truman requested an explanation from Ruppelt. CIA historian Gerald Haines noted Truman’s concern and the CIA’s formation of a special study group to review the situation. Edward Tauss reported for the group that most UFO sightings could be easily explained, but recommended continued monitoring.

The Robertson Panel ðŸ”—

This section describes the creation of the Robertson Panel in January 1953 due to the high number of UFO reports. The CIA and Air Force were concerned about potential mass panic and enemy exploitation. Howard P. Robertson chaired the panel, which consisted of prominent scientists. The panel dismissed most UFO cases and recommended that the Air Force and Project Blue Book focus on debunking UFO reports.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section notes the appearances of the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident in popular culture, specifically in the History Channel television series Project Blue Book and the Netflix series Top Secret UFO Projects Declassified.

item.title: UFO sightings in New Zealand
item.description:
UFO Sightings in New Zealand ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in New Zealand, noting that the New Zealand Defence Force does not officially investigate such reports but released files on purported sightings in 2010.

1950s ðŸ”—

This section details two reported sightings from the 1950s:

  • 1955: A National Airways Corporation aircraft captain reported a light with unusual movement, color changes, and intensity. The Director of Intelligence at the Carter Observatory attributed it to Venus.
  • 1959: A Blenheim farmer claimed to have seen lights and a UFO with two men in silver suits.

1970s ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the most widely reported incident, the Kaikoura lights.

  • December 21, 1978: A cargo plane crew reported strange lights over the Kaikoura Ranges. A Wellington radar team also reported inexplicable readings. A news crew filmed these events over several nights, attracting significant media attention in New Zealand and Australia.

2010s ðŸ”—

This section outlines UFO sightings reported during the 2010s:

  • April 12, 2011: A family in HÄwera observed and filmed a fireball-like UFO resembling a pyramid with a round top, which later appeared to “cool down” with a red ring. A member of the Hawera Observatory and Astronomical Society reported a similar incident a week prior, and a local dairy worker reported a similar sighting in January of the same year.
  • June 2016: A spherical UFO that rapidly changed colors was filmed near Christchurch. The object sped away after two hours. A second sighting involved two objects with coordinated color changes.
  • March 31, 2019: A couple at Karekare Beach in Western Auckland spotted two hovering lights 200 meters above the water. One object changed color and quickly flew away. The couple then spotted five other objects displaying erratic flight patterns and changing color.

2020s ðŸ”—

This section describes a sighting from 2020:

  • August 3, 2020: A woman in Porirua filmed three objects hovering over the city and shared the footage on a local Facebook group, where another resident confirmed seeing the same objects.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related topics and figures:

  • Bruce Cathie, a New Zealand author who has written about flying saucers.
  • UFO sightings in Australia.
  • List of reported UFO sightings.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including news articles from Stuff, The Press, Newshub, and The New Zealand Herald.

Further reading ðŸ”—

This section lists books related to UFOs in New Zealand. Authors include Erich von Daniken, Bill Startup, Mervyn Dykes, Peter Hassall, and Vicki Hyde.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites related to UFO research and sightings, including:

  • Ian Porritt UFO UAP Researcher
  • UFOCUS NZ
  • New Zealand sightings at UFOINFO
  • Original files: New Zealands’s UFO sightings

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_New_Zealand

item.title: UFO sightings in the United Kingdom
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in the United Kingdom ðŸ”—

This article documents notable alleged sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) in the United Kingdom. It notes the increased awareness of such sightings due to the release of the Ministry of Defence’s UFO sighting reports by the National Archives between 2008 and 2013. It also mentions that many recent sightings of slow-moving lights are often explained as Chinese lanterns. Project Condign, undertaken between 1997 and 2000, concluded that all investigated UK sightings of unidentified aerial phenomena could be attributed to misidentified objects or poorly understood natural phenomena. London is noted as the city with the most UFO sightings in the UK, followed by Manchester and Birmingham.

12th Century ðŸ”—

This section contains a single entry:

  • 1113: Religious pilgrims in South West England reported seeing a glowing, fire-belching “dragon” emerge from the sea, fly into the air, and disappear into the sky.

13th Century ðŸ”—

This section lists two alleged sightings:

  • January 1254: In St. Albans, a scribe recorded a sighting of a large, elegantly shaped ship of marvelous color in the sky.
  • 1290: Friars of Byland Abbey described a “flat, round shining silvery object” flying overhead. However, it’s noted that this report is considered a hoax perpetrated by teenagers in the 1950s.

20th Century ðŸ”—

This section covers alleged UFO sightings throughout the 20th century, broken down by decade.

1900s ðŸ”—

  • 1909: Sightings of a “mystery airship” over Ipswich, Cardiff, and Dublin. Referred to as a “scareship” or “phantom airship,” it had two visible lights and moved at a rapid rate. Mr. Chatten, a grocer’s assistant, saw a similar craft over Tharston in Norfolk. The Willows airships are mentioned as the first British airships.

1910s ðŸ”—

  • Late 1912: The “scareships” returned. A sighting occurred over Kent on 14 October 1912. Conservative MP William Joynson-Hicks questioned Winston Churchill in parliament about Britain’s airship capabilities.

1940s ðŸ”—

  • February 1942: Eileen Arnold in Cheltenham experienced an altered state and saw a large oval shape radiating light.
  • September 1942: Albert Lancaster, a guard at a radar site near Newbiggin-by-the-Sea, Northumberland, claimed to have been abducted by aliens.
  • 5 August 1944: Winston Churchill allegedly banned the reporting of a UFO incident involving a Royal Air Force reconnaissance plane intercepted by a metallic object. The plane’s crew supposedly photographed the object.

1950s ðŸ”—

  • 1 June 1950: A Gloster Meteor at RAF Tangmere encountered a “flying saucer” lit up with lights over Portsmouth. This led to the establishment of the Flying Saucer Working Party.
  • 14 August 1950: F/Lt Hubbard, an experienced pilot, saw a 50 ft-diameter disc UFO over the Royal Aircraft Establishment (RAE).
  • 26 August 1950: A woman in Stanton Drew, Somerset, reported seeing a bright saucer-shaped object hovering over a field.
  • 14â€“25 September 1952: Operation Mainbrace. A silver disc-shaped object followed a Gloster Meteor returning to RAF Topcliffe on 19 September. On 21 September, six RAF planes followed a spherical object over the North Sea. Flt Lt John Kilburn of 269 Squadron reported the incident. Roy Mason, later the Secretary of State for Defence, discussed it in parliament in 1959.
  • 21 October 1952: Two RAF pilots in a Gloster Meteor saw three disc-shaped objects at 35,000 ft in the Little Rissington UFO incident.
  • 9 October 1953: Two BEA pilots flying from London to Paris saw a saucer object over the English Channel. Captain Peter Fletcher and First Officer R L. Lemon were the pilots involved.
  • 3 November 1953: Terry Johnson and Geoffrey Smythe in an RAF de Havilland Vampire saw a UFO over RAF West Malling. The sighting was discussed in parliament, with the Secretary of State for Air, Nigel Birch, attributing it to a weather balloon.
  • 29 June 1954: A BOAC pilot in a Boeing 377 Stratocruiser saw seven UFOs over the North Atlantic. Captain James Howard, air hostess Daphne Webster, and First Officer Lee Boyd were involved. The incident was later discussed on BBC programs and in the House of Lords.
  • 14 October 1954: F/Lt James Salandin of the Royal Auxiliary Air Force narrowly missed two UFOs over Southend-on-Sea.
  • 17 July 1955: A 30-foot-wide saucer-shaped object was seen hovering over a street in Bexleyheath by Margaret Fry and her doctor.
  • 13 August 1956: Lakenheath-Bentwaters incident â€“ 12 to 15 objects were picked up by USAF radar over East Anglia.
  • 22 September 1956: A large, spherical glass-like object was seen over the Cleethorpes coast and on radar from RAF Manby.
  • 4 April 1957: West Freugh incident â€“ a large object was seen on radar at RAF West Freugh near Stranraer.
  • 29 April 1957: An unknown object was tracked by radar over the English Channel near Dover. Conservative MP Patrick Wall and Labour MP Frank Beswick discussed it in parliament.
  • 20 May 1957: Milton Torres 1957 UFO Encounter â€“ a USAF F-86D Sabre based at RAF Manston intercepted an object over East Anglia.
  • 21 November 1957: Silpho Moor UFO â€“ a small saucer-shaped container was discovered containing copper pages with messages in glyphs.

1960s ðŸ”—

  • Friday 9 February 1962: A Luton motor mechanic, Ron Wildman, saw an oval-shaped, glowing white object near Aston Clinton that disabled his car engine.
  • Monday 21 May 1962: Aer Lingus pilot Gordon Pendleton saw a moving object with no wings over Taunton in Somerset.
  • From late spring to early summer 1965: Many UFO sightings occurred in the Warminster area.
  • 28 April 1967: A dome-shaped object was sighted over Brixham in Devon.
  • 1967: Clapham Wood in West Sussex experienced a rash of UFO sightings.
  • 10 August 1967: Policemen Lionel Haw and Steve Parsonage saw a large white object in Hindley.
  • 2 September 1967: An object was seen over Stoke-on-Trent.
  • 24 October 1967: “Devon Flying Cross UFO” â€“ PCs Roger Willey and Clifford Waycott saw a bright cross-shaped object near Holsworthy. Christopher Garner also witnessed the object. The sighting was discussed in parliament by MPs Peter Mills and John Langford-Holt.
  • 25 October 1967: “Sussex Flying Cross” â€“ Policemen in East Sussex reported a bright flying cross. Wing Commander Eric Cox also saw a “fiery cross” in Hampshire.
  • 26 October 1967: Angus Brooks saw a circular translucent craft near Holworth in Dorset.

1970s ðŸ”—

  • 25 January 1971: Pat Otter of the Grimsby Evening Telegraph claimed that RAF aircraft were sent to investigate mysterious objects over the North Sea.
  • 1971: Unidentified silent craft were allegedly seen by schoolchildren near Muchalls, Scotland.
  • 25 May 1971: Eunice Rose saw a glowing object near Hinckley in Leicestershire that affected her car.
  • 12 August 1971: Olwyn Grainger and others saw a silent cylindrical object over a field near Wombourne. The British music group Henry Cow wrote a suite inspired by this event.
  • 16 October 1973: Gabriella Versacci claimed to have been taken aboard an alien spaceship near Langford Budville in Somerset.
  • 23 January 1974: A UFO allegedly crashed on the Berwyn Mountains in Wales.
  • 4 February 1977: A cigar-shaped craft allegedly landed next to Broad Haven Primary School, and children saw a silver creature.
  • Wednesday 16 February 1977: Nine girls and a teacher saw a mysterious object at Rhosybol in Anglesey

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_the_United_Kingdom

item.title: UFO sightings in Sweden
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Sweden ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged UFO sightings within Sweden.

1946 ðŸ”—

This section details two notable events from 1946. The first is the wave of “ghost rockets,” mysterious rocket-shaped objects sighted extensively in Sweden and nearby Scandinavian countries between May and December. Thousands of sightings were reported, with some tracked on radar and physical fragments allegedly recovered. The second event is the alleged Ã„ngelholm UFO incident, where businessman GÃ¶sta Carlsson claimed to have witnessed a UFO landing in a forest near Ã„ngelholm and encountered humanoid occupants.

2009 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the 2009 Norwegian spiral anomaly, a spiral-shaped light phenomenon observed over Norway and Sweden. The event involved a blue beam of light with a greyish spiral emanating from one end.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the main “List of reported UFO sightings” Wikipedia page, allowing readers to explore a broader range of global UFO incidents.

References ðŸ”—

This section contains a single reference to an article from Universe Today titled “What was the Norway Spiral?” by Nancy Atkinson, dated December 9, 2009.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides an external link to the MUFON (Mutual UFO Network) website, specifically to a page displaying the last 20 UFO sightings and pictures reported to the organization.

item.title: UFO sightings in Spain
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Spain ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Spain, organized chronologically by year.

1976 ðŸ”—

This section details an incident at the Talavera la Real Air Base in Badajoz province on November 12, 1976. Two soldiers, JosÃ© MarÃ­a Trejo and Juan Carrizosa LujÃ¡n, reported encountering a being of unknown origin. They heard unusual noises and saw a bright light. They described the being as approximately 3 meters tall, human-shaped, with a small head, long arms, and no apparent hands or feet. The soldiers claimed to have fired 40 to 50 bullets at the being, which then disappeared. An investigation by the Air Force confirmed that the soldiers fired their weapons, but no bullet casings or holes were found. Spanish Army veteran Vicente Juan suggests the soldiers experienced a hallucination.

1979 ðŸ”—

This section refers to the Manises UFO Incident, which occurred on November 11, 1979. This event involved a commercial flight making an emergency landing at Manises airport in Valencia due to a reported UFO encounter.

1981 ðŸ”—

This section mentions an event on July 24, 1981, where Prudencio Muguruza reportedly saw a bright light crash near Ochate. He took a photo of the event.

1994 ðŸ”—

This section notes a Tunguska-like event that occurred on January 18 in Cando, Galicia, Spain.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles, including the “List of reported UFO sightings” and “UFO sightings in the Canary Islands.”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including articles from El Mundo and Mundo Misterioso. The references provide verification and further information on the events described.

External links ðŸ”—

This section includes a link to MUFON (Mutual UFO Network) for recent UFO sightings and pictures.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Spain

item.title: UFO sightings in South Africa
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in South Africa ðŸ”—

This article documents reported sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs) in South Africa.

1914 Phantom Monoplanes ðŸ”—

This section details a series of sightings from August to September 1914, where numerous South Africans reported seeing a nighttime monoplane. These sightings occurred during the lead-up to the South West Africa campaign of World War I, leading to speculation that it was a German spy plane. However, the origin of the plane remained unknown, leading some to consider mass hysteria as a possible explanation. Key locations include various parts of South Africa.

1970s Sighting ðŸ”—

This section focuses on an incident from June 26, 1971, involving Bennie Smit, a farm owner near Fort Beaufort in the Eastern Cape. Smit and local police reportedly fired shots at a fireball-like object that changed color. Rumors circulated about an army investigation, though no records were found. The incident gained international attention, and local businesses capitalized on the event.

1990s Sightings ðŸ”—

This section covers several UFO sightings during the 1990s:

  • April 7, 1991: A family in Baviaanspoort, Pretoria, reported a triangular craft with red and white lights. Similar sightings occurred in nearby Eersterust.
  • November 18, 1993: Residents of Sasolburg observed lights moving from Vereeniging, describing a craft that could change color and shape.
  • Septemberâ€“October 1994: A farmer in Warrenton claimed to see a ‘mothership’ with a distinctive engine sound.
  • Marchâ€“April 1995: A UFO flap occurred across South Africa, with reports including a hovering object at De Brug, a spacecraft blocking a road near Coligny, and disruptions to vehicles and watches.
  • August 28, 1996: Police Sgt. Nico Stander in Pretoria videotaped lights in the sky, leading to a chase involving police and a helicopter near Cullinan.
  • July 1997: Andreas Mathios claimed to film a cylindrical light above Trichardt.
  • May 8, 2000: Police inspector Kriel reported observing an orange, oval-shaped light on the N3 freeway near Warden.

21st Century ðŸ”—

This section details UFO sightings in the 2000s and beyond:

  • June 27, 2004: Roshnie Naidu in Durban reported observing and videotaping a bright, colorful light changing shape.
  • 2009: Multiple people witnessed orange-red objects traveling between Middelburg and Witbank.
  • July 21â€“22, 2010: Residents of Booysens, Pretoria, reported seeing a triangle of bright lights.
  • Mayâ€“October 2011: Numerous reports of silent, orange lights over Tierpoort and Krugersdorp, with additional sightings near Harrismith.
  • November 2015: Residents in Pietermaritzburg and Clarendon reported seeing orange orbs, and a green light was reported over Long Street in Cape Town.
  • December 12, 2016: The captain and co-pilot of a Boeing 737 cargo aircraft reported seeing a glowing green object near Jeffreys Bay.

Crash Claims and Hoaxes ðŸ”—

This section addresses claims of alien spacecraft being shot down by South African aircraft in 1989 and 1995, which were later determined to be hoaxes.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the main “List of reported UFO sightings” article on Wikipedia.

Notes ðŸ”—

This section contains footnotes and references to support the information presented in the article, citing various news reports, books, and other sources.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites related to UFO research in South Africa, including scans of Cynthia Hind’s UFO Afrinews and the UfoRSA website.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_South_Africa

item.title: UFO sightings in Russia
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in Russia ðŸ”—

This article catalogs alleged sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) within Russia. It presents a list of incidents, each with a brief description and, where available, links to further information.

Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details specific alleged UFO sightings in Russia, spanning from the early 20th century to the early 21st century.

  • Tunguska Event (1908): While generally attributed to a meteor explosion, some propose that the Tunguska event in Siberia was caused by a UFO explosion.
  • Petrozavodsk Phenomenon (September 20, 1977): This event involved sightings of unusual aerial phenomena over Petrozavodsk and surrounding areas.
  • Usove, Soviet Ukraine (October 4, 1982): A UFO allegedly hovered over a nuclear missile launch facility, causing the activation of nuclear missiles.
  • Voronezh UFO Incident (1989): This incident involved reported sightings of a UFO and alleged encounters with extraterrestrial beings in Voronezh.
  • Sasovo Explosions (April 12, 1990, and July 8, 1992): Two mysterious explosions occurred in Sasovo, Ryazan Oblast, with force equivalent to 25 tons of TNT.
  • Otradnenskoye “UFO Fragment” (Early 2012): A titanium object, described as a “UFO fragment,” was found near Otradnenskoye in Novosibirsk Oblast after unusual sounds were reported. The object was U-shaped and not linked to space technology.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the general “List of reported UFO sightings” page on Wikipedia, allowing readers to explore a broader range of UFO incidents worldwide.

References ðŸ”—

10 May 1978, Emilcin ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the Emilcin Abduction, where a farmer in Emilcin claimed to have been abducted and examined by short, green-faced humanoid beings. The encounter allegedly took place inside a white, hovering craft. A memorial now stands at the site of the alleged abduction.

19 January 2009, JarnoÅ‚tÃ³wek ðŸ”—

item.title: UFO sightings in Norway
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Norway ðŸ”—

This article documents reported UFO sightings in Norway, spanning from 1986 to 2009. Each sighting includes a brief description, location, and any explanations or analyses provided.

1986 ðŸ”—

This section details a sighting that occurred on July 13, 1986, near Torpo. Married couples Tova and Tonning observed two bright objects in the sky, and Mr. Tonning filmed the event. The film was analyzed by Ground Saucer Watch (GSW), which found no evidence of a hoax but couldn’t definitively identify the objects due to a lack of reference points. Other experts suggested the objects were Jupiter and Arcturus.

2006 ðŸ”—

This section recounts a widespread sighting on August 21, 2006, where a bright, green orb was seen across northern Norway, from Finnsnes in Troms to BodÃ¸ in Nordland. Witnesses described the object as moving at great speed and being larger than an aircraft. Initially considered a possible UFO, the phenomenon was later attributed to a bolide.

2009 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the 2009 Norwegian spiral anomaly, which occurred on December 9, 2009. A bluish spiraling light was observed, filmed, and photographed over Norway. While the exact cause remains uncertain, Norwegian news sources attributed the event to a failed Russian missile launch. A link to the main article on the anomaly is provided.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the general “List of reported UFO sightings” page on Wikipedia, allowing readers to explore UFO sightings in other locations and contexts.

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including:

  1. Nordic UFO Newsletter-N. 1 -1988
  2. Norway in UFO Photographs
  3. “Strange ‘Norway spiral’ was an out-of-control missile” (New Scientist)

item.title: UFO sightings in Mexico
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Mexico ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Mexico, spanning from the late 19th century to the early 21st century. It presents specific incidents, including details, locations, and explanations where available.

1883 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the observations made by astronomer JosÃ© Bonilla on August 12, 1883, at the Zacatecas Observatory. Bonilla reported seeing and photographing numerous dark objects crossing the sun. Initially considered a potential early UFO photograph, the objects were later identified as high-flying geese. Despite the explanation, the event is still sometimes cited in ufological contexts.

1974 ðŸ”—

This section details the alleged mid-air collision between a UFO and a small airplane near Coyame on August 25, 1974. It mentions reports from local residents and claims of a subsequent military investigation and cover-up. However, it also presents an alternative explanation suggesting the reports were related to the crash and military recovery of a Cessna aircraft involved in drug trafficking.

2004 ðŸ”—

This section describes an incident on March 5, 2004, where Mexican Air Force pilots, using infrared equipment, recorded 11 unidentified objects over southern Campeche. The Mexican Defense Department released a press release and videotape of the event. Ufologist Jaime Maussan interpreted the footage as evidence of alien visitation. Skeptic Michael Shermer criticized the varying witness accounts, and other experts suggested the lights were likely burn-off flares from offshore oil platforms in the Gulf of Mexico.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of links to related topics, including a general list of reported UFO sightings and a specific link to an article about a UFO sighting over pyramids in Mexico.

External links ðŸ”—

item.title: UFO sightings in India
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in India ðŸ”—

This article catalogs reported UFO sightings in India, spanning from 1951 to 2023. Each entry includes the date, location, and a brief description of the event, often with links to news sources or related articles.

1951 ðŸ”—

This section details a report from New Delhi where members of a flying club observed a cigar-shaped object, estimated to be around one hundred feet long, in the sky. The source cited is NICAP (National Investigations Committee On Aerial Phenomena).

2004 ðŸ”—

This section recounts an incident on September 27, 2004, where scientists in Samudra Tapu (Chandra Taal) spotted a white, “snowman”-like object on a nearby mountain ridge. India Today speculated it could have been a spy drone or balloon.

2007 ðŸ”—

This section mentions a “fireball” photographed in the skies of Kolkata in October, which was claimed to be shape-shifting.

2013 ðŸ”—

This section lists two separate incidents. The first involves residents of Chennai observing five specks of bright orange light in the night sky in June. The second details how troops of the Indian Army spotted several UFOs near the Ladakh border in August.

2015 ðŸ”—

This section describes two separate incidents in Uttar Pradesh. In Gorakhpur, a resident claimed to have photographed a large UFO, but the photo was suspected to be digitally altered. In Kanpur, a boy reportedly captured a flying saucer in a photo of clouds taken with his father’s phone.

2023 ðŸ”—

This section details a recent event in November where a UFO was spotted over Imphal airport, causing a three-hour disruption to flight services. Two Indian Air Force Rafale fighter jets were scrambled, but the search was unsuccessful.

This section provides a link to the main “List of reported UFO sightings” Wikipedia page.

item.title: UFO sightings in Indonesia
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings within Indonesia ðŸ”—

This section presents a chronological list of reported UFO sightings in various locations across Indonesia. Each entry includes the city or region, the specific island or province, and the date of the alleged sighting, along with citations for verification.

  • Early Sightings (1953-1964): The earliest reported sightings occurred in Medan, Sumatra (January 28, 1953, and June 26, 1955), Malang, Java (February 21, 1953), Gorontalo, Sulawesi (February 23, 1953), Alor Island, East Nusa Tenggara (July 1959), Jakarta (1962), Surabaya, East Java (1964), and Yogyakarta, Yogyakarta Special Region (1964).
  • Sightings in the 1970s: Sightings were reported in Mount Agung, Bali (1973), and Jakarta (October 7, 1977, and November 11, 1977).
  • Sightings in the 1980s and 1990s: Sightings were reported in Yogyakarta, Yogyakarta Special Region (1980), Tarakan Island, East Kalimantan (1984), Jakarta (1986), Bandung, West Java (1989), Bali (1991), Probolinggo, East Java (1994), Salatiga, Central Java (July 1995 and September 1997), and Pengandonan (February 1996).
  • Sightings from 1998 to 2011: Sightings were reported in Mount Salak, West Java (April 16, 1998), Denpasar, Bali (February 3, 2000), Salatiga, Central Java (October 12, 2003), and Seminyak, Bali (March 18, 2011).

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles. These include a general list of reported UFO sightings and a specific list of UFO sightings in Australia.

This section lists the sources cited in the article. These references include news articles, websites, and books that provide information about the reported UFO sightings in Indonesia. The references are formatted as footnotes, with links to the original sources where available.
