item.title: UFO sightings in Iran
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings within the nation of Iran ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) in Iran.

1976 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the 1976 Tehran UFO incident. This event involved radar and visual sightings of a UFO over Tehran. Key aspects include electromagnetic interference affecting approaching F-4 jet interceptors, causing instrumentation and communication failures that were resolved upon retreat. One F-4 also experienced weapons system failure when preparing to engage the object. The incident is documented in a U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) report distributed to high-ranking officials and agencies. Iranian military officers involved publicly stated their belief that the object was extraterrestrial.

1982 ðŸ”—

This section mentions a mass sighting in Isfahan during the summer of 1982. Thousands of people reportedly witnessed a large reflection of an object in the sky. However, this event lacks a citation.

2003 ðŸ”—

This section details a sighting near the Caspian Sea in August 2003. Two tourists reported observing a couple of yellow-white colored UFOs.

2004 ðŸ”—

This section describes a mass UFO sighting event, known as the 2004 Iran UFO sighting, which occurred between April 12â€“21. Thousands of people witnessed the UFOs, and one was filmed by Iranian TV. The nature of the objects remains unclear, with possibilities including UFOs, surveillance aircraft, or the planet Venus. Photos surfaced, with some deemed unknown by UFO groups but others dismissed as hoaxes, conventional aircraft, or Venus.

2005 ðŸ”—

This section mentions a report from a tourist who claimed to have seen a UFO hovering near the Tomb of Cyrus the Great.

2007 ðŸ”—

This section discusses a reported UFO crash in the Barez Mounts of Kerman province. Eyewitnesses informed the Fars News Agency (FNA) about a radiant UFO crash. Abulghassem Nasrollahi, the Deputy General of Kerman province, confirmed that all aircraft in the area were accounted for but didn’t dismiss the possibility of a meteor. Another source told FNA that the object was on fire with thick smoke, suggesting it wasn’t a meteor. A similar incident was reported in Rafsanjan a few days prior.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related articles, including the “List of reported UFO sightings.”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including links to UFOinfo.com and BBC News articles.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Iran

item.title: UFO sightings in France
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in France ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged UFO sightings within France, spanning from the 9th century to the 1980s.

815 ðŸ”—

This section details an account from 815 AD in Lyons, Auvergne-RhÃ´ne-Alpes. Archbishop Agobard of Lyons wrote about people believing in a region called Magonia, from which ships came in the clouds. These ships supposedly transported fruits lost through hail and storms, with “aeronauts” paying weather witches. The account also mentions a crowd attempting to stone four people believed to have fallen from these ships, who were eventually saved.

1952 ðŸ”—

This section covers an event on October 17, 1952, in Oloron-Sainte-Marie. Multiple witnesses reported a cigar-shaped UFO accompanied by 30 disc-shaped objects. The smaller UFOs allegedly dropped a white siliceous cotton-like substance. Skeptics proposed alternative explanations, such as optical phenomena and spider migrations.

1954 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on a sighting on September 10, 1954, in Quarouble, Nord. A railway worker, Marius Dewilde, claimed to have seen two small beings boarding a UFO. The case garnered significant media attention.

1965 ðŸ”—

This section details two separate incidents. The first, on July 1, 1965, in Valensole, Alpes-de-Haute-Provence, involves farmer Maurice Masse’s alleged close encounter. Masse claimed to have encountered two small beings near a spherical vehicle. He said he was paralyzed by one of the beings and watched them examining plants. UFOlogists consider this case significant, citing “landing gear impressions” found in the soil. The second incident occurred in September 1965 in Fort-de-France, Martinique, where hundreds of witnesses observed a ball or disk of light moving slowly across the sky, leaving a glowing trail. Michel Figuet, a helmsman in the French fleet, reported the sighting.

1967 ðŸ”—

This section describes the “Close encounter of Cussac” on August 29, 1967, in Cussac, Cantal. Two children claimed to have witnessed a UFO and its occupants.

1976 ðŸ”—

This section recounts an event on November 5, 1976, near Rives/Voreppe, IsÃ¨re. A French physicist, Dr. S., reported seeing a luminous disk in the sky, brighter than the full moon. The same phenomenon was observed by multiple people over a 250-kilometer stretch.

1978 ðŸ”—

This section details an incident on June 19, 1978, in Gujan-Mestras, Gironde. Several people witnessed a UAP that allegedly caused a city-wide power outage. The local police and GEPAN investigated the case.

1981 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the Trans-en-Provence Case on January 8, 1981, in Trans-en-Provence, Var. UFOlogists consider this case significant due to alleged material traces left by a UFO. Critics suggest the traces were a hoax or caused by tires.

1982 ðŸ”—

This section describes an event on October 21, 1982, in Nancy, France. A biologist witnessed an ovoid object descending into a garden and hovering above the ground. After the object departed, the witness noted that nearby amaranth plants had withered leaves. The Gendarmerie investigated, and GEPAN analyzed plant samples, finding dehydration but no radiation.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles, including “List of reported UFO sightings.”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, news articles, and websites.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites, including the CNES (French Space Agency) UFO data website and the MUFON (Mutual UFO Network) website.

item.title: UFO sightings in China
item.description:
UFO Sightings in China ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) in China.

1994 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on “The Meng Zhaoguo Incident,” a purported close encounter of the third kind that Meng Zhaoguo claimed to have experienced in Phoenix Mountain, Wuchang, Heilongjiang. In 1994, Meng reported seeing a white, shining object descend into the mountain. He claimed to have been harassed by entities, taken aboard their spacecraft, and forced to copulate. He also stated that he was shown images of Jupiter, which the entities claimed was their homeworld. The UFO Enthusiasts Club at Wuhan University examined his story and concluded that while the initial contact might have occurred, the subsequent events were likely untrue. Other UFO groups in China, however, believed his claims.

2010 ðŸ”—

This section details a UFO sighting that occurred on July 7 above Hangzhou Xiaoshan International Airport near Hangzhou. The airport was temporarily closed due to the sighting. An investigation found no radar images and determined that the purported images of the UFO were not taken near the airport. The investigation concluded that the object may have been an aircraft, possibly military.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the “List of reported UFO sightings” for broader context.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including news articles and websites.

item.title: UFO sightings in Brazil
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in Brazil ðŸ”—

This article catalogs reported UFO sightings in Brazil, spanning from 1947 to 2020. It presents a chronological list of incidents, including eyewitness accounts, investigations, and related controversies.

1947 ðŸ”—

This section details an alleged encounter in Bauru, SÃ£o Paulo, where topographer JosÃ© Higgins and his laborers witnessed a lens-shaped object landing. Higgins reported communication with humanoid figures who emerged from the craft.

1952 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on a reported sighting near Barra da Tijuca by journalist Joao Martins and photographer Eduardo Keffel, who claimed to have photographed a flying disk. The photos were published in O Cruzeiro magazine.

1957 ðŸ”—

This section covers several notable events:

  • The Ubatuba incident, involving fragments of pure magnesium purportedly from a UFO that exploded over Ubatuba beach. Journalist Ibrahim Sued received the fragments and a letter describing the event. Ufologist James Harder believed the fragments to be of extraterrestrial origin.
  • Antonio Villas Boas’s alleged abduction by extraterrestrials, one of the first widely publicized alien abduction stories.
  • An incident at Itaipu Fort in Praia Grande, SÃ£o Paulo, where sentinels suffered burns from a heat wave emanating from a descending UFO. The fort’s electricity went out during the event. The Brazilian Army, the United States Air Force (USAF), and the Brazilian Air Force investigated. Donald Keyhoe of the USAF offered his opinions on the case.

1958 ðŸ”—

This section describes a sighting by the crew of the Brazilian ship Almirante Saldanha near Ilha de Trindade. Captain Viegas and others witnessed a ringed flying object similar to Saturn. Almiro BaraÃºna reportedly photographed the object.

1966 ðŸ”—

This section highlights the Lead Masks Case near NiterÃ³i, where two men were found dead wearing lead masks. A UFO was allegedly seen flying near the location of their deaths. It also mentions the creation of SIOANI (ServiÃ§o de InformaÃ§Ã£o de Objetos AÃ©reos NÃ£o Identificados), an office created to investigate UFO sightings northwest of SÃ£o Paulo.

1977 ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the Colares UFO flap, a series of sightings on Colares Island where UFOs allegedly attacked citizens with radiation beams. This led to the Brazilian government’s Operation Saucer (OperaÃ§Ã£o Prato), an investigation by the Brazilian Air Force.

1979 ðŸ”—

This section details the alleged abduction of Antonio Carlos Ferreira, a security guard in Mirassol, SÃ£o Paulo. He claimed to have been taken aboard a spacecraft by humanoid figures, shown images, and forced to mate with a female alien.

1980 ðŸ”—

This section mentions the experience of Elias Seixas de Mattos, a truck driver from Rio de Janeiro, and his two friends, who reported an unexplainable encounter.

1982 ðŸ”—

This section describes a mass sighting during a 1982 Campeonato Brasileiro SÃ©rie A match between OperÃ¡rio-MS and CR Vasco da Gama at the MorenÃ£o stadium. Over 24,000 spectators, including players and the referee JosÃ© de Assis AragÃ£o, reported seeing flying objects. Ademar JosÃ© Gevaerd, a prominent Brazilian ufologist, was a witness.

1986 ðŸ”—

This section covers the 1986 Brazilian UFO incident, a series of sightings across southeastern Brazil that led to jet fighters being scrambled. Pilots reported the UFOs’ ability to make sharp turns and fly at hypersonic speeds.

1995 ðŸ”—

This section describes an incident on January 12, 1995, where a luminous object was seen falling onto a farm in JaÃ­ba district, Feira de Santana, Bahia. A major power outage occurred in nearby cities shortly after.

1996 ðŸ”—

This section details two incidents:

  • The Varginha UFO incident, involving reports of UFOs and strange creatures (allegedly extraterrestrials) in Varginha, Brazil.
  • Haroldo Westendorff’s sighting of a cone-shaped UFO at Patos Lagoon. He reported flying around the object and a smaller object emerging from it. The sighting was also detected by radar at Pelotas’ airport.

2008 ðŸ”—

This section covers two cases:

  • The “Dossier RiolÃ¢ndia,” produced by Inape, which allegedly documents UFO sightings in RiolÃ¢ndia on January 20, 2008.
  • The Claudio Case in ClÃ¡udio, Minas Gerais, where military police chased luminous humanoid creatures and photographed UFOs. The case report includes photographs and a police report.

2013 ðŸ”—

This section mentions a light seen during the 2013 protests in Brazil. Initially reported as a UFO, it was later believed to be a drone used by Folha de S. Paulo newspaper for aerial photography.

2020 ðŸ”—

This section describes sightings in MagÃ©, Rio de Janeiro, where residents recorded videos of strange lights and objects in the sky.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Brazil

item.title: Michigan "swamp gas" UFO reports
item.description:
1966 US UFO Sightings: Michigan “Swamp Gas” UFO Reports ðŸ”—

This article details the mass sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) that occurred in Michigan during March 1966, specifically on March 20 and 21. These events became known as the “Michigan ‘swamp gas’ UFO reports” due to the Air Force’s controversial explanation for the sightings.

March 1966 UFO Flap ðŸ”—

This section provides an overview of the broader context of the Michigan UFO sightings, noting that the Dexter and Hillsdale mass sightings occurred amidst a wave of UFO reports throughout southern Michigan. A map illustrates the locations of reported sightings, including Lima, Milan, Dexter, Hillsdale, and Holland.

Initial Reports ðŸ”—

This section details the initial UFO sightings that preceded the Dexter and Hillsdale incidents. It mentions reports from Washtenaw County residents, sheriffs, and police beginning around 3:50 a.m. on March 14, describing lights moving at high speeds over Lima Township. Sightings were also reported from Monroe, Livingston, Ypsilanti, Dexter, and Sylvania. Sheriff Deputies Buford Bushroe and John Foster, along with personnel at Selfridge Air Force Base, confirmed the sightings. Deputy David Fitzpatrick captured photographs of lights over Milan on March 16.

Dexter Mass Sighting ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the events of March 20, 1966, when Frank Mannor, his wife, and son Ronald reported seeing a red “falling star” that hovered over a marshy area near their farmhouse northwest of Dexter. Mannor contacted law enforcement, and Deputy Sheriff Stanley McFadden and his partner David Fitzpatrick investigated. The Mannors described the object as football-shaped with a ‘waffled’ texture, blinking lights, and antennae. Dexter patrolman Robert Hunawil and Dexter Chief of Police Robert Taylor were also witnesses. Approximately 60 people, including law enforcement, neighbors, and the Mannor family, reportedly witnessed the UFO.

Hillsdale Mass Sighting ðŸ”—

This section describes the mass sighting that occurred around 9 p.m. on March 21 at Hillsdale College. Approximately 87 residents of the MacIntyre Residence Hall observed flashing lights hovering over the Arboretum. William Van Horn, Hillsdale County civil defense director, investigated and observed the lights through binoculars. Hillsdale police officers Harold Hess and Jerry Wise also witnessed the object and reported radio damage after the event.

Continued Reports ðŸ”—

This section notes that reports of flying objects, strange sounds, and unexplained lights continued in Dexter and Hillsdale on March 22. On March 23, a teen from Monroe claimed to have taken photos of a UFO. Robert Nichols and his wife reported an object flying across a highway near Holland on March 24. Sightings were also reported over Macomb and Oakland counties, as well as Bad Axe, Flint, and Ann Arbor, on March 29.

National Attention ðŸ”—

This section discusses the national media coverage of the Dexter sightings, noting that papers nationwide reported on the events on March 21. Wire services distributed a drawing of the reported object by a police officer. Various speculations were covered, including a theory that the UFO was filling up on swamp water to recharge its batteries.

Hynek Press Conference ðŸ”—

This section details the involvement of J. Allen Hynek, an Air Force UFO expert, who was dispatched to investigate the Dexter and Hillsdale sightings. On March 25, Hynek held a press conference where he attributed the sightings to “marsh gas,” an explanation that was met with skepticism and derision. He dismissed the Fitzpatrick photograph as being of the moon and Venus.

Reactions ðŸ”—

This section describes the reactions to Hynek’s “swamp gas” explanation. Congressman Gerald R. Ford called for a Congressional investigation into the sightings. Life Magazine and CBS Reports covered the case.

Congressional Hearing ðŸ”—

This section discusses Hynek’s testimony before the House Armed Services Committee on April 6, alongside Air Force Secretary Harold Brown and Bluebook chief Major Hector Quintanilla. Hynek broke with the Air Force’s stance and suggested that some aspects of UFOs merited serious study.

Aftermath and Legacy ðŸ”—

This section examines the long-term impact of the Michigan UFO sightings. The sightings were listed as a top-ten story for 1966 in Michigan. Alan Hynek, who popularized the swamp gas hypothesis, later argued that the topic merited serious study. The phrase “swamp gas” became associated with skepticism of government conclusions. The incident has been referenced in popular culture, including The X-Files and Men in Black.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan_%22swamp_gas%22_UFO_reports

item.title: UFO sightings in outer space
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Outer Space ðŸ”—

This article discusses reported sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs) by astronauts while in space. These sightings are often cited by ufologists as potential evidence of extraterrestrial life. However, the article also presents counterarguments and explanations for these sightings, often attributing them to misidentified objects, debris, or other natural phenomena.

Incidents ðŸ”—

This section details specific instances where astronauts have reported seeing unusual objects during space missions.

  • Gemini 4: Pilot Jim McDivitt reported seeing a “white cylindrical shape with a white pole” and took pictures. McDivitt believes it was man-made debris, while James Oberg suggests it was the Titan II second stage.
  • Gemini 7: Astronauts mentioned a “bogey” in a transcript, which some ufologists interpreted as a UFO. James Oberg argues it was booster debris. Astronaut Frank Borman confirmed it was not a UFO.
  • Apollo 11: Stories circulated about Neil Armstrong witnessing UFOs during the Apollo 11 mission. Armstrong claimed he saw two blue pale glowing orbs. Explanations suggest these could have been jettisoned components. Science fiction writer Otto Binder perpetuated a hoax about this event. Buzz Aldrin clarified that he observed a light alongside the crew.
  • International Space Station (2005): Astronaut Leroy Chiao reported seeing lights in a formation during a spacewalk. Initially promoted as a possible UFO sighting, Chiao later identified the lights as fishing boats.
  • International Space Station (2013): Astronaut Christopher Cassidy reportedly saw a UFO near the Progress 52 cargo ship. Russian flight controllers identified it as an antenna cover from the Zvezda service module.
  • International Space Station (2020): Cosmonaut Ivan Vagner posted a video on Twitter featuring UFOs on a time-lapse of the Aurora Australis, dubbing them “space guests.” He later clarified that they seemed to be satellites.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles, including:

  • List of reported UFO sightings
  • STS-48 (specifically mentioning ice particles)

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited within the article, including news articles, scientific papers, and websites. Key references include:

  • NBC News article debunking myths about Neil Armstrong’s UFO sightings.
  • James Oberg’s analysis of astronaut UFO sightings.
  • Popular Mechanics article discussing NASA’s “UFO” videos.
  • Huffington Post article about astronaut Leroy Chiao’s UFO sighting.
  • Fox News report on NASA identifying a UFO as an antenna cover.
  • CTV News report on Cosmonaut Ivan Vagner’s video of apparent UFOs.

Further reading ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about UFO sightings in outer space. These include books, articles, and online resources. Key entries include:

  • Franklin E. Roach’s chapter on visual observations made by U.S. astronauts in the Condon Report.
  • James R. Hansen’s biography of Neil Armstrong, which discusses the Apollo 11 UFO incidents.
  • James Oberg’s article “Astronauts and UFOs: The whole story.”
  • Carl Sagan’s book The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites related to UFO sightings and NASA’s perspective on the topic. Key links include:

  • NASA’s Solar System Exploration Research Virtual Institute page on Buzz Aldrin’s UFO sighting.
  • NASA’s Solar System Exploration Research Virtual Institute page on the Apollo 11 UFO sighting.
  • James Oberg’s website with frequently asked questions about astronauts and UFOs.
  • NASA News Topics article titled “UFO No longer unidentified.”

UFOs Template ðŸ”—

This section contains a template linking to various UFO-related topics on Wikipedia, including:

  • Ufology
  • Claimed sightings
  • Types of UFOs
  • Types of alleged extraterrestrial beings
  • Studies and timeline
  • Hypotheses

item.title: List of UFO organizations
item.description:
UFOs and Ufology ðŸ”—

This section provides a general overview of the topic, linking to the main articles on Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs) and Ufology, the study of UFOs. It includes an image of a “flying saucer” from the National Archives and Records Administration. It also links to a list of notable UFO sightings.

Notable Sightings ðŸ”—

This section lists various notable UFO sightings and incidents, categorized chronologically and geographically. Some key events include:

  • 1947 Wave: The surge of UFO sightings in 1947, marking the beginning of the modern UFO era.
  • 1952 Flap: A series of UFO sightings over Washington, D.C.
  • Barney and Betty Hill Incident: A famous alleged alien abduction case.
  • Belgian Wave: A series of UFO sightings over Belgium in the late 1980s and early 1990s.
  • Calvine Photo: A controversial UFO photograph from Scotland.
  • Chiles-Whitted Encounter: A 1948 sighting by commercial pilots.
  • Flatwoods Monster: A West Virginia sighting of a strange creature.
  • Gorman Dogfight: A 1948 encounter between a pilot and a UFO.
  • Kenneth Arnold Sighting: The event that popularized the term “flying saucer.”
  • Mantell Crash: The death of a pilot while pursuing a UFO.
  • Mariana Film: A 1950 UFO sighting filmed in Montana.
  • McMinnville Photos: A set of photographs purportedly showing a UFO.
  • Rendlesham Forest Incident: A series of reported sightings near a US military base in the UK.
  • Roswell Incident: The alleged crash of a UFO in Roswell, New Mexico.
  • Sightings in Outer Space: UFO sightings reported by astronauts.
  • “Swamp Gas” Reports: UFO reports attributed to natural phenomena.
  • Pentagon UFO Videos: Declassified videos of UFOs recorded by US Navy pilots.
  • Phoenix Lights: A mass sighting of lights over Phoenix, Arizona.

Hoaxes ðŸ”—

This section lists notable UFO-related hoaxes, including:

  • Alien Autopsy Hoax: A purported film of an alien autopsy.
  • Travis Walton Incident: A controversial alleged alien abduction case.

Government Investigations ðŸ”—

This section lists various government investigations into UFOs from different countries, including:

  • OperaÃ§Ã£o Prato (Brazil): A Brazilian military investigation into UFO sightings.
  • Project Magnet (Canada): A Canadian government UFO study.
  • GEIPAN (France): A French government UFO investigation unit.
  • Institute 22 (Soviet Union): A Soviet military research program.
  • Flying Saucer Working Party (UK): An early British government investigation.
  • Project Condign (UK): A later British government study.
  • History of Government Investigations (US): A general overview of US government involvement.
  • All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office (US): A current US government office for investigating UFOs.
  • NASA’s UAP Independent Study Team (US): A NASA team studying UAPs.
  • Condon Committee (US): A controversial US government study that concluded UFOs posed no threat.
  • Project Blue Book (US): A long-running US Air Force investigation into UFOs.
  • Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena Disclosure Act (US): A US law aimed at disclosing information about UAPs.

Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section lists popular UFO-related conspiracy theories, including:

  • Area 51: A secret US military base rumored to house alien technology.
  • Bob Lazar: A man who claims to have worked on alien technology at Area 51.
  • Majestic 12: An alleged secret group of government officials tasked with managing UFO information.
  • Men in Black: Mysterious figures who allegedly harass UFO witnesses.
  • Serpo: A purported exchange program between the US and aliens from the planet Serpo.

Religions ðŸ”—

This section lists religions that incorporate UFOs and extraterrestrial beings into their belief systems, including:

  • Aetherius Society: A religious group that believes in communication with extraterrestrial beings.
  • Church of the SubGenius: A parody religion that incorporates UFOs and conspiracy theories.
  • Heaven’s Gate: A religious group that committed mass suicide in the belief that they would ascend to a spaceship.
  • Nation of Islam: An Islamic religious movement that believes in a “Mother Plane” or UFO.
  • RaÃ«lism: A religion that believes extraterrestrials created humanity.
  • Scientology: A religion that incorporates extraterrestrial beings and events into its cosmology.
  • Unarius Academy of Science: A religious group that believes in communication with advanced extraterrestrial civilizations.

Lists of Organizations, Sightings, Studies, etc. ðŸ”—

This section provides links to various lists related to UFOs, including:

  • UFO organizations
  • Reported UFO sightings
  • Sightings by country
  • Investigations of UFOs by governments
  • Identification studies of UFOs
  • Ufologists
  • Alleged extraterrestrial beings

List of UFO Organizations ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of notable non-governmental UFO organizations located around the world.

Belarus ðŸ”—

  • UfoCom: A UFO research organization in Belarus.

Estonia ðŸ”—

  • AKRAK: An inactive UFO research organization in Estonia.

France ðŸ”—

  • COMETA: A French association that published a report on UFOs.

Sweden ðŸ”—

  • Archives for the Unexplained (AFU): A Swedish archive dedicated to UFO research.

Russia ðŸ”—

  • Kosmopoisk: A Russian research group that investigates anomalous phenomena, including UFOs.

United Kingdom ðŸ”—

  • British UFO Research Association (BUFORA): A UK-based UFO research organization.

United States ðŸ”—

Active ðŸ”—

  • All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office (AARO): A US government office for investigating UFOs.
  • Center for the Study of Extraterrestrial Intelligence (CSETI): An organization that seeks to establish contact with extraterrestrial civilizations.
  • Center for UFO Studies (CUFOS or JAHCUFOS): A UFO research organization founded by J. Allen Hynek.
  • International UFO Congress (IUFOC): An annual conference on UFOs.
  • Mutual UFO Network (MUFON): A large international UFO research organization.
  • National UFO Reporting Center (NUFORC): A US-based organization that collects and disseminates UFO sighting reports.
  • To the Stars (TTS): A company that researches and disseminates information about UFOs.

Inactive/Defunct ðŸ”—

  • Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program (AATIP): A former US Department of Defense program that studied UFOs.
  • Aerial Phenomena Research Organization (APRO): A former UFO research organization.
  • Citizens Against UFO Secrecy (CAUS): A former organization that advocated for government transparency on UFOs.
  • Civilian Saucer Investigation (CSI-LA): A former UFO research group in Los Angeles.
  • Civilian Saucer Intelligence (CSI-NY): A former UFO research group in New York.
  • Fund for UFO Research (FUFOR): A former organization that provided funding for UFO research.
  • National Institute for Discovery Science (NIDSci): A former privately funded research institute that investigated UFOs.
  • National Investigations Committee On Aerial Phenomena (NICAP): A former prominent UFO research organization.
  • UFO Investigators League (UFOIL): A former UFO research group.
  • Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force (UAPTF): A former US Navy task force that investigated UFOs.

See Also ðŸ”—

  • List of investigations of UFOs by governments
  • Identification studies of UFOs
  • Ufology

item.title: UFO Hunters
item.description:
UFO Hunters ðŸ”—

UFO Hunters is an American television series that aired on the History Channel from 2008 to 2009, spanning three seasons. The show explores the realm of ufology, pseudoscience, and conspiracy theories, with each episode focusing on investigations into reported UFO sightings and related phenomena.

Format ðŸ”—

The show follows investigations led by William J. Birnes and his team of experts. The team includes researchers, engineers, and biologists who investigate reports of unidentified aerial phenomena, interview witnesses, analyze evidence, and consult with other experts to determine the validity of UFO reports. The team investigates long-standing UFO cases, such as the Roswell incident, and other famous sightings.

Series overview ðŸ”—

The series consists of three seasons, with a total of 39 episodes. Season 1 premiered on January 30, 2008, and concluded on May 7, 2008, with 13 episodes. Season 2 aired from October 29, 2008, to February 25, 2009, also with 13 episodes. Season 3 premiered on March 18, 2009, and concluded on October 29, 2009, with 13 episodes.

Episodes ðŸ”—

Season 1 (2008) ðŸ”—

Season 1 explores various UFO-related topics and incidents. Key episodes include “The UFO Before Roswell,” which examines the Maury Island incident in Washington, and “USOs,” which investigates unidentified submerged objects off the coast of Santa Catalina Island, California. “Abductions” revisits the Betty and Barney Hill case in New Hampshire, while “Crash and Retrieval” delves into UFO crash cases in Coyame and Xilitla, Mexico. Other episodes cover military encounters with UFOs, police reports involving UFO sightings, rumors of reverse engineering of alien technology, UFO hotspots like the Hudson Valley and Stonehenge, alien contact experiences, mass UFO sightings in Texas, UFO dogfights involving Iranian and Peruvian fighter pilots, military air traffic controllers tracking UFOs, and NASA’s potential knowledge of UFOs.

Season 2 (2008â€“09) ðŸ”—

Season 2 continues the investigation into UFO phenomena with episodes such as “Invasion Illinois,” which examines a mass sighting event in Tinley Park, Illinois. “UFO Emergency” reopens police cold cases involving mass UFO sightings in Trumbull County, Ohio, Holland, Michigan, and Millstadt, Illinois. “Heartland Explosion” investigates a mysterious boom and fiery object sighting in Kokomo, Indiana. “Aurora First Contact” researches the 1897 UFO crash in Aurora, Texas. “The Real Roswell” explores rumors of a crash site in Aztec, New Mexico. “Arizona Lights” investigates a mass sighting of a triangular craft over the Nevada/Arizona border and connections to the Phoenix Lights incident. “Lost UFO Files” delves into the archives of UFO investigator James E. McDonald. “Alien Fallout” examines close encounters of the second kind, such as the Cash-Landrum incident. “UFO Storm” investigates a wave of UFO hysteria in the United Kingdom. “Giant UFOs” probes sightings of gigantic unidentified craft over England and the United States. “Aliens at the Airport” investigates encounters between commercial aircraft and UFOs at O’Hare International Airport in Chicago and Osaka, Japan. “Alien Crashes” examines the crash of an unknown object in Needles, California, and the Kecksburg, Pennsylvania, incident. “Area 51 Revealed” explores recent activity at Area 51.

Season 3 (2009) ðŸ”—

Season 3 investigates various UFO-related topics. “Giant Triangles” examines black triangle reports in Sonora, California. “Underground Alien Bases” explores claims about the Dulce Base in New Mexico. “The Greys Conspiracy” investigates alien abduction cases involving Grey aliens. “Underwater Alien Bases” delves into reports from Gulf Breeze, Florida, and GuantÃ¡namo Bay, Cuba. “Nazi UFOs” investigates rumors of the Third Reich’s involvement with alien technology and the Die Glocke project. “Alien Harvest” examines cattle mutilations in Norwood, Missouri, and black helicopter sightings in Trinidad, Colorado. “UFO Relics” studies physical evidence from UFO sightings in Poland and Missouri. “Underwater Area 51” monitors activity at the Atlantic Undersea Test and Evaluation Center (AUTEC). “UFO Surveillance” analyzes videos and accounts suggesting a UFO presence at Brookhaven National Laboratory and Lawrence Livermore Laboratory. “Dark Presence” investigates orb phenomena in Arizona, Indiana, and Missouri. “First Response” explores military protocols for UFO incidents near Long Beach, California, and Needles, California. “The Silencers” delves into cases involving the Men in Black. “Area 52” investigates the Dugway Proving Ground in Utah.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_Hunters

item.title: Gulf Breeze UFO incident
item.description:
Gulf Breeze UFO Incident ðŸ”—

The Gulf Breeze UFO incident refers to a series of claimed UFO sightings that occurred in Gulf Breeze, Florida, between November 1987 and May 1988. The events gained widespread attention after the Gulf Breeze Sentinel newspaper published photographs purportedly showing a UFO, provided by local contractor Ed Walters.

Events of November 11, 1987 â€“ May 1, 1988 ðŸ”—

Ed Walters claimed to have been immobilized by a blue beam on November 11, 1987, after which he took photos of a UFO hovering near his home. He reported multiple subsequent encounters, taking more photos and even videotaping the object. Walters also claimed to have witnessed the craft landing and aliens exiting, communicating with him telepathically in English and Spanish, and even being lifted off the ground by a blue beam. He reported a total of nineteen sightings or encounters. On one occasion, he claimed the UFO leaked a liquid that continued to boil for weeks.

Investigation ðŸ”—

Walters initially provided his photographs to the Gulf Breeze Sentinel anonymously. He later admitted to being the photographer and submitted to a polygraph test, which indicated he believed his photos were real. Walters also claimed to have experienced missing time on three prior occasions and under hypnosis, stated he had been abducted by aliens.

Several individuals investigated the claims. Ray Stanford initially questioned the weather data related to the photos but later conceded they were likely taken on the reported day. Phillip Klass dismissed the photos as inauthentic. Robert Nathan from NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory suggested the images were double exposures or manipulated. Ed Gray, the mayor of Gulf Breeze, also concluded the photos were fake.

Budd Hopkins believed Walters’ claims were genuine, citing his polygraph test and refusal of a book deal. Bruce Maccabee found a good chance the photos were real. Willy Smith from UNICAT suggested a support under the UFO in the photos indicated it was a model.

Eglin Air Force Base, located near Gulf Breeze, reported no unusual activity or radar blips during the alleged sightings. Gulf Breeze’s police chief, Jerry Brown, attributed the sightings to hysteria and misidentification of activity at the base.

Eyewitness Reports ðŸ”—

Following the publication of Walters’ photos, numerous other residents reported sightings in the Gulf Breeze area. These reports described orange glows, beams of light, and oval or oblong crafts. Fenner McConnell and his wife Shirley claimed to have seen a disc-shaped aircraft with no wings. Brenda Pollak, a Gulf Breeze councilwoman, reported seeing an orange light and witnessed Walters taking photos of a UFO at Shoreline Park. Santa Rosa County Commissioner John Broxson also claimed to have seen unusual lights. Other residents, like Art and Mary Hufford, and Jeff Thompson, reported seeing similar objects. A tollbooth operator, Jerry Thompson, reported seeing thirteen pink-lighted objects.

UFO Research Group Response ðŸ”—

Supporters of Walters, particularly within MUFON, viewed the mass sightings as evidence of the phenomena’s authenticity. MUFON’s director, Walter Andrus, considered the Gulf Breeze incident their “best case ever.” Donald Ware, MUFON’s Florida director, believed the aliens wanted the photos to be seen.

CUFOS, founded by J. Allen Hynek, deemed Walters’ photos fake due to inconsistencies in the craft’s windows and waviness suggesting reflection off water. Friends of Walters reportedly described him as a prankster who had planned “the ultimate prank” and noted parallels between his story and Whitley Streiber’s book Communion.

Model Discovered ðŸ”—

In 1990, a model resembling the UFO in Walters’ photos was found in the attic of his former home. The model was made of foam plates and drafting paper. Craig Myers of the Pensacola News Journal reported the discovery and was able to duplicate Walters’ photos using the model. Walters denied any knowledge of the model, claiming it was planted.

The discovery of the model caused division within the UFO community. Supporters claimed it was planted, while others expressed doubt in Walters’ claims. It was also revealed that Walters had received a $200,000 book advance and was offered $450,000 for miniseries rights. Additionally, he had a prior criminal record for forgery and auto theft, for which he received a pardon from Governor Bob Martinez.

Renewed Interest After 1990 ðŸ”—

UFO sightings continued at the Pensacola Bay Bridge into 1991. In 1993, a friend of the Walters family admitted to witnessing Ed faking the UFO pictures. Mark Curtis also reported that Walter and his wife had divorced in November 1992, splitting $2.5 million in assets believed to have come from the hoax.

MUFON held its first annual UFO symposium in Pensacola in 1990, which continued for the rest of the decade. The publicity attracted tourists and UFO sightseers, boosting the local economy.

In the Media ðŸ”—

The Gulf Breeze UFO case was featured on Unsolved Mysteries and a TV special called “UFO Cover-UP…Live!”. Eyewitness Shirley McConnell discussed her experience on A Current Affair. Unsolved Mysteries, Inside Edition, and A Current Affair filmed more UFO shows in July 1990.

In a 1994 episode of The X-Files, Fox Mulder mentions the Gulf Breeze UFO photos, stating he knew they were fakes.

Gulf Breeze singer Ken Manning won an award for his song “Gulf Breeze UFO” in 1999.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_Breeze_UFO_incident

item.title: UFO sightings in the Canary Islands
item.description:
UFO Sightings in the Canary Islands ðŸ”—

This is a list of alleged sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) in the Canary Islands. The article has been flagged for needing additional citations, requiring cleanup, and having multiple issues.

Sightings ðŸ”—

This section lists specific dates of reported UFO sightings in the Canary Islands:

  • 1974 â€“ 24 November: A sighting is recorded on this date.
  • 1976 â€“ 22 June: This sighting is notable due to its duration (over 40 minutes), multiple locations (Tenerife, La Palma, La Gomera, Gran Canaria, and a ship at sea), and numerous witnesses (hundreds of people, including civilians and military personnel). Two witnesses reported seeing occupants inside the craft, but this account is considered dubious by Antonio Munaiz, a military judge who wrote the Spanish government report, and Carlos Dolz de Espejo, the lieutenant general of the Air Force at the time. The official report by the Spanish Air Force was declassified in June 1994, with much of its content released earlier in 1977 by journalist and paranormal investigator J.J. Benitez, who used it for a book on UFO cases.
  • 1976 â€“ 19 November: Another sighting is noted on this date.
  • 1979 â€“ 5 March: A final sighting is listed for this date.

See also ðŸ”—

This section contains a link to the “List of reported UFO sightings” Wikipedia page.

References ðŸ”—

item.title: UFO sightings in Nepal
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Nepal ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Nepal.

25 March 1968 ðŸ”—

This section details a significant event that occurred around 8:15 pm in Batulechaur, Pokhara. Residents reported witnessing a “blazing object” accompanied by a loud thunderous sound, which appeared to disintegrate over the Kaski region. Following this event, a large metallic disk-shaped object was discovered in a crater in Baltichaur, approximately five miles northeast of Pokhara. Additional fragments of a similar object were found in Talakot and Turepasal. The CIA documented this event. Kevin D. Randle mentions in his book “Moon Dust” that the American embassy in Kathmandu sent a secret message to the 1127th USAF Field Activities Group and the 1006th at Fort Belvoir, requesting full cooperation from the Nepalese government, under the subject “MOON DUST”.

20 March 2020 ðŸ”—

This section describes a more recent event in Gandaki province. A bright, “burning” object was observed flying towards Earth, followed by a crashing sound. The Astronomical Society urged people to provide evidence of the sighting.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the “List of reported UFO sightings” Wikipedia page.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article:

  1. A CIA “Information Report” documenting the 1968 incident.
  2. An article from the Kathmandu Post titled “How the US kept tabs on UFO sightings and Yeti hunting in Nepal,” referencing the 1968 event.
  3. Kevin D. Randle’s book, “Project Moon Dust,” specifically Chapter 8, which discusses the history of Project Moon Dust.
  4. An article from The Himalayan Times titled “Astronomical society urges people to provide evidence on sighting,” covering the 2020 event.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Nepal
